awd_titl_txt: RCN Proposal: Macroecology of Infectious Disease
awd_abstract_narration:
Scientists from multiple disciplines, including wildlife biology, public health, veterinary parasitology and biomedical sciences, have compiled a wealth of data on the distribution and impacts of infectious diseases, with most studies focused on particular locations or single host-pathogen interactions. This wealth of data creates the opportunity to address a pressing need, namely to explore the patterns and drivers of infectious disease emergence in humans and natural ecosystems at global scales. This project will create a Research Coordination Network to bring together internationally recognized experts from ecology, conservation medicine, parasitology and computational sciences to quantify and explore the drivers of global scale patterns of pathogen biodiversity. Participants will work together to assemble data sets of unprecedented size, including information about disease occurrence in host species ranging from insects to humans. With help from experts in machine learning (artificial intelligence) and geographic information systems (GIS), they will work to build predictive models that can be used to understand the changing distributions of infectious diseases and identify future hotspots of novel disease emergence in humans and wildlife.

Emerging infectious diseases, especially those that jump from wildlife to livestock and humans, threaten public health around the world. Using state of the art computational methods, the RCN will be able to answer critical questions such as: How and why do certain pathogens successfully move from one host species to another? Are hotspots of pathogen biodiversity in wildlife the same areas as hotspots of disease emergence in humans and livestock? To share its findings, the RCN will develop educational products such as webcasts and workshops aimed at educational levels from high school to post graduate, and will train students from under-represented groups through a summer research program. The RCN will also develop and maintain databases of global infectious disease biodiversity and make these data freely available to the academic community and the general public.

inst.inst_name: University of Georgia Research Foundation Inc
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF GEORGIA RESEARCH FOUNDATION, INC.

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of the Macroecology of Infectious Disease Research Coordination Network was to bring together internationally recognized experts in macroecology (regional to global ecological patterns and processes), infectious disease ecology, conservation medicine, statistical modelling and machine learning methods, geospatial analysis, and evolutionary biology to form a collaborative group and investigate global-scale disease dynamics.  Overall the network included participants from six countries and 24 universities

We addressed questions of great interest both from the perspective of basic science, and of critical concern to human health.  For example, one of the most pressing concerns for society is predicting  which pathogens and disease events have the potential to cause a global pandemics.  We have approached this basic question from two different perspectives. One study looked at the factors that determine the overall geographic range of pathogens and parasites, investigating how the the characteristics of disease causing organisms that remain confined to small regions differ from those that become globally distributed.  A key finding is that pathogens that can infect a wider variety of host species, particularly a large number of close evolutionary relatives, tend to be the ones with larger geographic ranges.  Another study characterized how the driver and pathogen profile of a typical outbreak, which in modern times generally consists of 40 or fewer cases, differs from that of a large outbreak with thousands to hundreds of thousands of cases.  We found that large outbreaks are caused more often by viral than bacterial pathogens, and that the drivers of large outbreaks tend to be broad-scale factor such as contamination of water supplies, unusual weather conditions, poor sewage management, and population explosions in insect vectors such as mosquitos.   

Other topics we investigated included how to most accurately map global patterns of biodiversity in parasitic organisms, new methodological approaches that can be used to better characterize host-parasite networks despite highly incomplete and spatially biased data, how direct ecological interactions such as predation have affected global patterns of parasite sharing among host species, and what future hotspots of zoonotic disease risk may appear due to the influence of climate change.  At the time of this writing, 38 scientific publications facilitated by the RCN have been published or are in peer review.  We also published the Global Mammal Parasite Database v. 2.0, which contains records of more than 24,000 host-parasite associations collected from 2700+ literature sources, and made the Ecological Database of the Worlds Insect Pathogens once again available to the public (for nearly a decade it was no longer availble to researchers due to being archived in a proporietary data format).  To enhance adoption of both of these resources we also created public websites with graphical user interfaces allowing users to explore data, easily subset them to host and pathogen species of interest, and select categories of data for download. 

In addition to academic publications and databases, the RCN produced over a dozen miscellaneous educational products and other resources  We produced four tutorials about computational methods in the R programming language, and two new R libraries.  We produced three youtube videos aimed at explaining basic concepts of disease macroecology to the public, power point presentations that allow educators to easily incorporate disease macroecology concepts into their lessons, and one full self-contained lesson suitable for a lecture and associated lab exercise a data science or disaese ecology course. 

The RCN also had an impact on diversity in STEM. Both our meetings and our research teams were demographically diverse, including women, minorities and participants in a wide variety of career stages from undergraduates to senior researchers.  To help further promote diversity and participation in  STEM, we also distributed a dozen travel grants to facilitate undergraduate research on large-scale disease dynamics. We encouraged sponsors to consider diversity when choosing students to nominate, and in the end most were awarded to female and / or minority individuals. To see a full list of publications and other RCN products see the public website of the RCN: http://diseasemacroecology.ecology.uga.edu/


Last Modified: 10/30/2021
Modified by: Patrick R Stephens
